conversation.content: [formally] I was told you're the only die caster within five hundred miles who can work with dragon scale alloy. [pause] My armor took significant damage in the battle at Thornhaven, and I need replacements for the chest piece and gauntlets.

Dragon scale alloy, yes, I can work with it. [coughs] Though most people don't realize it requires temperatures above three thousand degrees and specialized flux compounds that cost more than most houses.

[confidently] Money isn't an issue, I've been well compensated by the kingdom for my services. [quickly] The dragon that destroyed Thornhaven's granaries is dead, and they were grateful enough to ensure I can afford whatever I need.
[very quietly] Thornhaven. [long pause] So you're the one who killed the beast last month, the famous dragon slayer everyone's been talking about in the taverns and markets.

[relieved] Finally, someone who doesn't want to hear the whole story again. [exhales] I've had to recount that battle dozens of times, and frankly, I just need my armor fixed so I can move on to the next contract.
[bitter] The next contract. [slowly] Of course, there's always another dragon to slay, another town to save, another heroic deed to add to your legend, isn't there?
[confused] Is there a problem with the commission? [firmly] Look, if you don't want the work, just say so, but I was told you were professional enough to handle this without the attitude.
[controlled] No problem at all, I'll take the job. [clearing throat] I just need to know if you want the same design as before or if you'd like modifications based on what failed during the battle.

The dragon's fire was hotter than expected, melted right through the standard alloy mix. [thoughtfully] If you could increase the tungsten content by fifteen percent, that should handle anything I encounter going forward.

Fifteen percent more tungsten will make it heavier, probably add eight pounds to the total weight. [coldly] But I suppose collateral damage is less of a concern when you're protected by the finest armor money can buy.

[sternly] Collateral damage is always a concern, but dragons don't exactly wait for civilians to evacuate before attacking. [passionately] Every second I waste is another building burned, another family that doesn't make it to safety.

Safety. [laughs bitterly] Right, because a sixteen-year-old girl running from her workshop definitely had time to reach safety when the great hero brought the dragon crashing down through the artisan quarter.
[very quietly] The artisan quarter. [gasps softly] You're talking about the building collapse on West Street, where the dragon's tail brought down three shops when I drove my spear through its heart.

[shaky voice] Her name was Elisa, she was learning the trade from me, had real talent with the fine detail work. [crying while speaking] She was going to take over the business someday, had all these ideas about new alloy combinations.

[regretful] I didn't know there were apprentices working that late. [very quietly] The town guard told me the workshops were empty, that everyone had evacuated to the temple grounds when the warning bells rang.

[furious] The guard lied because they wanted you to kill it quickly, before it reached the wealthy district! [shouting] My daughter died because they decided some neighborhoods were worth more than others!
[empathetically] God, I'm so sorry. [slowly] If I had known anyone was still in those buildings, I would have led the dragon elsewhere, even if it meant more damage to my armor or risk to myself.
Your armor. [exhales] You know what? I'll still make your damn armor, because I need the money to leave this place, start over somewhere that doesn't remind me of her every single day.

[hesitantly] I'll pay triple your rate, and I'll make sure the kingdom provides compensation for your loss. [firmly] It won't bring her back, but maybe it can help you rebuild somewhere else, honor her memory properly.
[exhausted] Just leave the damaged pieces and come back in two weeks. [very quietly] And next time you save a town, remember that heroes and monsters both leave bodies in their wake.

scenario: A legendary dragon slayer seeks out a master die caster to forge replacement armor, not knowing the craftsman's daughter was killed in the collateral damage of their last battle.
